messages: a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:12): needs something like unrealism which is a real world :)

edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:21): comment 27 gets really funny at the end
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:21): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c might appreciate reading it
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:22): (the comment from Vasil Rangelov that is, in case they remove earlier comments)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:31): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: the same post also talks about XML Schema and XHTML 1.2...
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:31): yeah :)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:33): it's something I could have written when I didn't really comprehend how Web browsers and the Web evolve
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:35): oh, seems the Apple keynote started
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:37): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: ended, too
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:42): apart from the DRM-free stuff it doesn't seem very interesting
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:44): well, iWork.com is interesting implementation-wise, but I most likely won't use it

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:46): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: sadly none of the existing tools convert html to rdf. Maybe anolis could convert html to one of the other formats that is then converted to rfc? :-)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:46): er, s/rdf/rfc/
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:46): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: DanC definitely pointed me to one beore
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:46): *before
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:46): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: (no rush, btw, please do pass your exams)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:47): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I maintain my position of "ask DanC".
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (22:51): what's interesting about the iWork implementation>?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:51): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: Also, it really ought to be an entirely separate tool. How xref is done for HTML makes no sense for text/plain.
47223c0fa41aa7e167a2d1fd2740cbb8 (22:52): seconds 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427's question

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:53): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427: I haven't looked at the impl, but if they advertise same layout as in Pages, I'm intrested in line breaking fidelity and ligatures
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (22:54): is it Web-standards based or a plugin thing?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:55): I don't know. I assumed HTML&CSS without evidence
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (22:55): then I have no idea how they'd achieve that
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:58): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: fair enough
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:59): iwork.com claims to support only Firefox 3 and Safari 3

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:59): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: on an unrelated note, it would be cool to have a template for anolis a bit like the template bert made, that happens to be w3c pubrules-compliant
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (22:59): doesn't support IE?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:59): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I also have no interest in writing such a thing, because xml2rfc fulfils my use-case fine, and I'm not your slave :P
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:59): "For best performance and to use all iWork.com features, use one of the following supported browsers: Safari 3 or later; Firefox 3 or later"
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:59): says http://publish.iwork.com/shareddocuments/?a=x
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:00): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: What sort of template? Just a basic outline of a W3C spec?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:00): it's also interesting how exporting to Word can work in any satisfactory way
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:00): last time I tried exporting from Keynote to PowerPoint (versions ago), the result was useless
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:00): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: Also: email me.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:01): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: address?

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:01): ...but they've gone to effort of doing things like <meta http-equiv="X-UA-Compatible" content="IE=EmulateIE7" /> so I guess they care a bit about IE, and maybe it'll still mostly work in there
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:01): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: me a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554.com
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:03): done
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:04): goes back to writing notes on Nabokov's "The Enchanter"
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:04): (in HTML, of course)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:05): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: bug me on the 22nd if I haven't done anything by then
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:25): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: Should fictional speech be marked up using q?

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:45): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: "Content inside a q element must be quoted from another source, whose address, if it has one, should be cited in the cite attribute. The source may be fictional, as when quoting characters in a novel or screenplay."
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:46): Oh, I missed that bit.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:46): is n00b
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:46): wonders whether to use ISBN URNs in @cite
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:55): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: if you click an ISBN URN, will a book come down the wire? if not, then I suggest not.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (23:58): wonders how many people will add postal addresses to @cite
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:04): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: If you have Firefox with an extension installed, it can take you to a site to buy it :P
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:04): (i.e., no)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:04): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: http://dret.net/netdret/docs/wilde-cacm2008-xml-fever.html#web-blindness is possibly even more apt currently
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:07): that entire document is spot on and priceless
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (00:13): "Things that are priceless just cost more."
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (00:23): is someone accusing HTML5 of not knowing how to refuse things again?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (00:23): I guess we'll have to remove @headers again
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:24): who's complaining we're not saying no enough?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:25): i just said no like a dozen times in the last 24 hours
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (00:26): from Preston on public-html
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:31): ah

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:33): you know, i look forward to october, and going to last call. people are always ragging on about how html5 has a long timeframe, but hell, it's moving faster than, e.g., DOM3 Events, or many parts of CSS, and at least we have a real timetable that we're sticking to.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:33): reminds me of http://ln.hixie.ch/?start=1172653243&count=1
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (00:49): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: A link to the book's entry in http://www.worldcat.org/ might be more practical.
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (00:49): or to a particular page in Google Books.
